questions.text: Which of the following is the most common interstitial lung disease?
questions.solution:
The most common interstitial lung disease (ILD) is idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

ILD refers to the remodeling of interstitial space, the region between the epithelium and endothelium. The main pathology is fibrosis, mediated by TGF-ß and platelet-derived growth factor.

Classification of Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD)

ILDs of known etiology

  • Occupational: Coal worker's pneumoconiosis, silicosis
  • Treatment-related: Radiation, drug-induced
  • Connective tissue disease-related: Rheumatoid arthritis, Sjogren's syndrome, scleroderma

ILDs of unknown etiology

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF): Most common type 
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP)/Hamman-Rich syndrome
  • Respiratory bronchiolitis associated ILD (RBILD)
  • Desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
  • Pleuroparenchymal fibroelastosis

Granulomatous

  • Sarcoidosis
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

Other forms

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
  • Pulmonary Langerhans' cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)

Nintedanib oral capsules, small-molecule inhibitor of tyrosine kinase receptor, PDGFR & VEGFR, was recently approved by the FDA to treat patients with chronic fibrosing interstitial lung diseases (ILD) with a progressive phenotype.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman was found to have a restrictive disease with reduced lung volumes on a pulmonary function test. A high-resolution CT of the thorax was done and is shown below.  Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above HRCT shows a honeycomb appearance of lung parenchyma due to interstitial fibrosis in a restrictive lung disorder that is suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD). Inspiratory coarse crackles are not a feature of interstitial lung disease.

Auscultating a patient with ILD will reveal bilateral basal end-inspiratory fine crackles also called velcro crackles or rales.

Patients with interstitial lung disease usually present with a non-productive cough and breathlessness on exertion. Clubbing may be seen on examination, especially in advanced cases.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with breathlessness on exertion and dry cough for 4 weeks. She has swollen joints and early morning stiffness for which she is on treatment for a few years. On auscultation, inspiratory fine crackles were heard. An HRCT was ordered and it showed bilateral, subpleural and basilar honeycombing pattern. PFT of the patient is likely to show which of the following patterns?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the HRCT findings are suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD). FEV1/FVC ratio >0.7 and decreased DLCO are likely to be seen in the PFT. A history of swollen joints and early morning stiffness hints at rheumatoid arthritis. It is associated with the usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern of ILD.

In ILD, restrictive pattern is seen on pulmonary function test, which is characterized by:

  • Decreased total lung capacity (TLC)
  • Decreased forced vital capacity (FVC)
  • Decreased residual volumes (RV)
  • Decreased DLCO (diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide)
  • FEV1/FVC ratio - normal or increased, >0.7

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic HRCT finding of usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP)?

choices.text: Honeycombing and loss of lung architecture

questions.solution:
Ground-glass opacities on HRCT are not a characteristic finding in UIP.

Honeycombing, loss of lung architecture, traction bronchiectasis, and basilar subpleural reticular opacities are seen in UIP pattern of ILD on HRCT. 

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is also known as Hamman-Rich syndrome?
questions.solution:
Acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP) is also known as Hamman–Rich syndrome.

AIP is a rare, idiopathic, fulminant interstitial lung disease (ILD) that is similar in presentation to ARDS. It is often preceded by a viral upper respiratory tract infection.

Histologically, it shows diffuse alveolar damage. HRCT shows bilateral patchy, ground-glass opacities. Lung biopsy shows diffuse alveolar damage with hyaline formation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with dyspnoea. General physical examination revealed deformity of the hand as shown below. There is restricted mobility in the small joints and loss of wrinkle lines on the facial skin. An HRCT of the thorax showed diffuse subpleural, symmetric, ground-glass opacities of the lungs. Which of the following histopathological finding is likely to be seen in the lung biopsy of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing sclerodactyly suggestive of scleroderma along with the HRCT findings point to a diagnosis of non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP). It is characterized by homogeneous interstitial involvement.

NSIP is often associated with connective tissue disease but can also be drug-induced. The common drugs implicated in NSIP are:

  • Bleomycin
  • Busulfan
  • Methotrexate
  • Amiodarone

It usually affects middle-aged woman who have never smoked. There is uniformity of interstitial involvement across the biopsy section, and this may be predominantly cellular or fibrosing. HRCT shows homogenous involvement with symmetrical ground-glass opacities.

Non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) responds to steroids. Other treatment modalities include cytotoxic drugs like azathioprine or cyclophosphamide and also biologics like rituximab.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a smoking-related interstitial lung disease (ILD)?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is not related to smoking.

It is usually seen in young females with tuberous sclerosis. LAM can lead to pneumothorax or chylous effusions. 

Pulmonary function testing usually reveals an obstructive or mixed obstructive-restrictive pattern. HRCT shows thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma. 

The smoking-related ILDs are:

  • DIP - Desquamating interstitial pneumonia.
  • RB-ILD - Respiratory bronchiolitis associated ILD.
  • LCH - Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

questions.text: A man presented with progressively worsening cough with sputum, breathlessness, easy fatiguability, and loss of appetite for 6 months. PFT was suggestive of a restrictive disorder.  Trans-bronchial biopsy showed cells positive for CD1a and langerin (CD207). Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?

choices.text: They may present with spontaneous pneumothorax
Cysts and nodules are seen on HRCT
It is a smoking related interstitial lung disease

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). It is a smoking-related ILD that typically affects young adults. Smoking cessation leads to improvement in the condition.

The specific immunohistochemical markers for LCH are CD1a and langerin (CD207). On electron microscopy, the presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is characteristic (as shown below).

HRCT shows bilateral irregularly shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe. There is a risk of spontaneous pneumothorax in this condition due to cyst rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding pulmonary alveolar proteinosis?

choices.text: Acquired due to antibodies formed against GM-CSF

questions.solution:
Chunky, gelatinous, PAS-positive sputum is a feature of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP).

PAP is a condition characterized by the accumulation of surfactants in alveoli and terminal airways. It can be due to impaired clearance or abnormal production of surfactants. 

PAP can be of three forms:

  • Primary (most common): There is impaired GM-CSF-dependent surfactant clearance by the alveolar macrophages. It can be due to: 
    • Autoantibodies against GM-CSF (acquired/idiopathic/autoimmune PAP) 
    • Mutation in GM-CSF receptors (hereditary PAP) 
  • Secondary: There is a reduction in the number or ability of alveolar macrophages that causes impaired surfactant clearance. It can be due to:
    • Silicosis
    • Immunodeficiency disorders
    • Hematopoietic disorders and malignancies
  • Congenital: It affects neonates and children. There is abnormal surfactant production due to mutation in the genes coding for:
    • Surfactant protein B
    • Surfactant protein C
    •  ATP binding cassette protein member 3

About 30% of patients are asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients can have persistent dry cough, progressive dyspnea, and pleuritic chest pain

X-ray shows bilateral, diffuse opacities and HRCT shows a crazy-paving pattern (as shown below). The treatment is whole lung lavage.

questions.text: Farmer’s lung is associated with which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Farmer’s lung is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused due to exposure to mouldy hay, which contains thermophilic actinomycetes, principally Thermopolyspora polyspora.

questions.text: A daily-wage worker from the cement industry got a chest X-ray as a part of his routine health check-up. What could be the cause of the findings shown below?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows irregular opacities, which appear to be pleural thickenings i.e., pleural plaques. The sign along with a history of working in the cement industry suggests a diagnosis of asbestosis.

Workers of the cement, shipping, and textile industries are at a higher risk of developing asbestosis. Asbestos tends to involve the pleura first. 

The earliest manifestation is benign asbestosis-related pleural effusion. With time, the plaques calcify resulting in the formation of thick pleural plaques. The pleural thickenings can be seen on the X-ray. This is the “holly leaf sign”.

Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years). They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea. It predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes.

Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.

The image below shows thick plueral plaques.

questions.text: A woman has been working for a company that manufactures roofing sheets for 12 years, but the company does not provide her with personal protective equipment. Which of the following cancers is commonly seen in such individuals?
questions.solution:
Workers in the roofing industry are exposed to asbestos. Lung cancer (of all histologic types) is the most common cancer associated with asbestos exposure.

Smoking along with asbestos exposure multiplies the risk to a great extent. Cough and hemoptysis are common presentations.

Pleural mesothelioma is the most specific cancer associated with asbestos exposure, but not the most common. Smoking does not seem to be associated with mesothelioma. Pleuritic chest pain or a mass on the radiographic image are common presentations.

questions.text: Which among the following is a common concern for a patient presenting with chronic dry cough, working in the granite mining industry?
questions.solution:
Silicosis is a common concern for people working in granite mining industries.

Silica is found in rock, granite, slate, and sandstone. People working in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, glass and cement manufacturing, and quarrying are exposed to silica. The active molecule that causes silicosis is free silica or crystalline silica (quartz).

Silicosis can present as:

  • Acute silicosis - due to heavy exposure in closed spaces and they manifest within 2 years.
  • Chronic silicosis (simple silicosis) - due to long-term (10 to 30 years), less intense exposure.
  • Complicated silicosis-  simple silicosis may progress to complicated silicosis that presents with chronic cough and progressive dyspnoea on exertion.

Note: Silicosis is the most common pnemoconiosis in the world.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with an acute onset of dyspnoea. He tells you that he has been working in the sandblasting industry for about a year and the company does not provide personal protective equipment. He also gives a history of on and off dry cough. CT scan shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A history of working in the sandblasting industry for about a year without PPE suggests a heavy exposure to silica. This along with the CT finding of bilateral nodules, interstitial fibrosis, and crazy pavement pattern suggests a diagnosis of acute silicosis.

Acute silicosis is seen rarely. It manifests within 2 years of heavy exposure. Common presentations are dyspnoea and hypoxemia.

The X-ray may show diffuse miliary infiltrates or consolidation. HRCT may also show bilateral centrilobular nodules and ground-glass opacification. Bronchoalveolar lavage yields a PAS-positive milky white fluid.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has recently started work in the stone cutting industry. The company provides him with a respirator mask but they do not use dust control measures. If he works in similar conditions for 20 more years, which of the following will you most likely see in his HRCT scan image?

choices.text: Small round opacities in upper lobes
Thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma

questions.solution:
In this scenario, the man works in the stone cutting industry, indicating exposure to silica. He is expected to have less intense, long term exposure owing to a few but substandard measures to control exposure to silica. Such individuals are more likely to develop simple silicosis. These patients are asymptomatic, and HRCT shows small round opacities in the upper lobes.

This can progress to complicated silicosis. Here, the nodules coalesce and form masses leading to impairment of lung function. They present with chronic cough and progressive dyspnoea on exertion. This may progress further to cause progressive massive fibrosis. 

PFT shows a mixed obstructive and restrictive pattern. Calcification of hilar lymph nodes is seen in a few cases, called eggshell calcification. This is depicted in the image below.

Option A: A crazy pavement pattern is seen with acute silicosis.

Option C: Thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma are seen in pulmonary lymphangiomyomatosis (LAM).

Option D: Pleural plaques are seen in patients suffering from asbestosis.

Related Pearl: Lobes involved in various lung diseases

Mnemonic to easily remember the lobe of lung involved in CTD is:

Upper Lobe - CHARTS

  • Coal workers pneumoconiosis (CWP), silicosis, berylliosis
  • Histiocytosis X (LCH)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis, ABPA
  • Radiation
  • Tuberculosis
  • Sarcoidosis

Lower lobes - RAIDS

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Asbestosis
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
  • Drugs: bleomycin, busulfan, amiodarone, methotrexate, nitrofurantoin
  • Scleroderma

questions.text: Which of the following pneumoconiosis is associated with an increased incidence of tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Silicosis is associated with an increased incidence of tuberculosis.

Silica causes pulmonary alveolar macrophage dysfunction and hence, patients with silicosis have a higher risk of developing lung infections from organisms like M. Tuberculosis, atypical mycobacteria and fungi.

Radiographic imaging of silicotuberculosis shows cavitation.

questions.text: Choose the correct option with respect to Caplan’s syndrome.
questions.solution:
Caplan's syndrome also called rheumatoid pneumoconiosis, is a combination of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis.

It manifests as pneumoconiotic nodules along with features of seropositive rheumatoid arthritis. Caplan syndrome was first described in coal miners and later in patients with silicosis too.

Option C: Hilar adenopathy, polyarthritis, and erythema nodosum are characteristic of Lofgren syndrome.

Option D: Arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis are characteristic of Reiter syndrome.

questions.text: A factory worker presents to the clinic with fever, tiredness, and a chronic dry cough. He says his symptoms are worst on the first day of the week, improve by the end of the week, and are almost non-existent over the weekends. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above characteristic pattern of symptoms is called Monday fever or Monday chest tightness and is due to byssinosis. 

Byssinosis is seen commonly in cotton factory workers due to cotton dust exposure. It is also caused due to flax, hemp, and jute dust.

It is due to occupational hypersensitivity reaction with symptoms occurring (or recurring) on the first day of the workweek and diminishing by the weekend due to development of tolerance.

questions.text: Which interstitial lung disease is likely to be seen in a patient suffering from systemic sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) pattern of ILD is the most common pulmonary manifestation in systemic sclerosis.

The CT scan of NSIP shows ground-glass opacities. It responds to steroids given along with azathioprine or cyclophosphamide.

Other connective tissue diseases associated with ILD:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Sjögren syndrome
  • Dermatopolymyositis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who has worked as a miner for the past 25 years, comes to the OPD with complaints of dyspnoea and cough. Pulmonary function tests and a lung biopsy are done. The histopathology of the sample is shown below. Which type of emphysema can this condition give rise to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the microscopic image showing abundant black-colored pigment within the macrophages of lung parenchyma is characteristic of pulmonary anthracosis/coal worker's pneumoconiosis. It may give rise to centrilobular emphysema.

The inhaled carbon particles are engulfed by the lung macrophages.  They accumulate in the connective tissue along lymphatics or in lymphoid tissue along the bronchi or the hilum, which causes the blackening of the tissues. Aggregates of carbon dust are present as coal macules or nodules which consist of carbon-laden macrophages.

It is commonly seen in people who work in environments where there is high air pollution with carbon particles, such as coal mines. It is usually benign and less than 10% of the cases develop progressive massive fibrosis which may lead to pulmonary dysfunction, pulmonary hypertension, and cor pulmonale. Coal workers may also develop emphysema or chronic bronchitis, independent of smoking.

Unlike asbestosis, this condition does not predispose to cancer.
